citations.narrative:
The shelter building for the coyote and foxes has no means of providing ventilation when the animals are secured in the
building. There is no electricity to this building and the windows were closed and the door is not able to be opened due to
containment concerns. The area was hot and stuffy when the door was opened as there was no fresh air circulating in the
building. Ventilation needs to be addressed when animals are locked in this building to provide for their comfort and well
being.

Storage for perishable food supplies needs to be addressed. Currently apples and potatoes for the animals are stored out
on a counter in the porcupine barn and due to heat and humidity are beginning to spoil and show signs of mold growth.
Perishable food items need to be refrigerated to protect the food supplies from deteriorating and contamination.

The cavy enclosure was recently cleaned, but the outdoor pad is not draining, and water is pooling up in several areas of
the enclosure. The water is pooling just outside the shift door where the cavy’s must walk if they want to go outside. This
enclosure needs to be addressed to ensure that excess water can be rapidly eliminated for the health of the animals.

The shelter for the bobcat needs to be cleaned. There was an accumulation of bones from previous feeds in the shelter
area that has not been removed. These bones can contribute to pests in the area and should be removed and cleaned as
often as necessary for the health of the animal.

Housekeeping needs to be addressed in the shelter area for the cavy’s, crested porcupines, coati mundi and chinchilla’s.
This area is filled with miscellaneous items (hoses, tools around old food, excess wire and crate doors etc) haphazardly
left around the area and animal enclosures. This area needs to be kept clean to facilitate good housekeeping and
husbandry practices around the animals.
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant.
All items must be in compliance within (2) more inspection(s) or by Sept 26, 2025 or the applicant will forfeit the license
fee and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection.
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
n

narrative:
3.125(b) 
   
Facilities, general. 
The shelter building for the coyote and foxes has no means of providing ventilation when the animals are secured in the 
building. There is no electricity to this building and the windows were closed and the door is not able to be opened due to 
containment concerns. The area was hot and stuffy when the door was opened as there was no fresh air circulating in the 
building. Ventilation needs to be addressed when animals are locked in this building to provide for their comfort and well 
being. 
3.125(c) 
   
Facilities, general. 
Storage for perishable food supplies needs to be addressed. Currently apples and potatoes for the animals are stored out 
on a counter in the porcupine barn and due to heat and humidity are beginning to spoil and show signs of mold growth. 
Perishable food items need to be refrigerated to protect the food supplies from deteriorating and contamination. 
3.127(c) 
   
Facilities, outdoor. 
The cavy enclosure was recently cleaned, but the outdoor pad is not draining, and water is pooling up in several areas of 
the enclosure. The water is pooling just outside the shift door where the cavy’s must walk if they want to go outside. This 
enclosure needs to be addressed to ensure that excess water can be rapidly eliminated for the health of the animals. 
3.131(a) 
   
Sanitation. 
The shelter for the bobcat needs to be cleaned. There was an accumulation of bones from previous feeds in the shelter 
area that has not been removed. These bones can contribute to pests in the area and should be removed and cleaned as 
often as necessary for the health of the animal. 
3.131(c) 
   
Sanitation. 
Housekeeping needs to be addressed in the shelter area for the cavy’s, crested porcupines, coati mundi and chinchilla’s. 
This area is filled with miscellaneous items (hoses, tools around old food, excess wire and crate doors etc) haphazardly

left around the area and animal enclosures. This area needs to be kept clean to facilitate good housekeeping and 
husbandry practices around the animals. 
 
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the 
applicant. 
 
All items must be in compliance within (2) more inspection(s) or by Sept 26, 2025 or the applicant will forfeit the license 
fee and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection. 
 
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires. 
 
 n

species.common: RED FOX (INCLUDES SILVER FOX & CROSS FOX)
